awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Exploring the Ground-Level and Elevated Sources of New Particle Formation Using Aerosol Size- and Hygroscopicity-Resolved Turbulent Flux Measurement Technique
awd_abstract_narration:
This EAGER project is a "proof of concept" effort to evaluate a new method for assessing new particle formation events in the atmosphere.  A method has been developed to distinguish between ground-based and elevated sources of ultrafine particles by measuring the vertical fluxes of size-resolved particles and their ability to absorb water. Understanding new particle formation is critical to estimating ground level particle concentrations and designing effective air quality control strategies in urban areas.

The objectives of the study are to evaluate if: (1) measurements of eddy covariance and size-selected and hygroscopicity-resolved relaxed eddy accumulation (Hy-RES REA) vertical fluxes of particles can be used to separate ground-level and elevated sources of new particle formation; and (2) residual layer new particle formation events can be unambiguously linked to observed Class B nucleation events (during Class B events the smallest detected particle diameters are larger than about 10 nm in size) detected at the surface. During May of 2020, measurements will be made of size- and hygroscopicity-resolved vertical turbulent aerosol fluxes during 4 different time periods over the day at the Department of Energy's Southern Great Plains (SGP) site in Oklahoma, where a wealth of ancillary data are available, including long-term statistics of the diurnal boundary layer dynamics and diurnal profiles of aerosol number and hygroscopicity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The atmosphere is filled with microscopic particles, often termed "nanoparticles"or "aerosols". Although individual particles are invisible to the human eye, they affect cloud formation, human health, air quality, and the Earth's climate. A large number of these particles are produced through a complex process known as new particle formation. Laboratory experiments, field observations, and model simulations have helped researchers to identify some factors such as the intensity of solar radiation, ambient temperature and relative humidity, the concentration of precursor gases, and preexisting atmospheric particles that influence the frequency, strength, and spatial extent of new particle formation events. However, none of these factors can explain and predict new particle formation consistently in different parts of the world. This makes it difficult to accurately represent the processes of new particle formation in regional and global climate models.

There is mounting evidence that new particle formation events detected at the ground level can originate above the surface. Nucleation occurring aloft can be favored due to colder temperatures, lower preexisting particle concentrations, and higher relative humidity further up in the atmosphere. Because of this, ground-level measurements may not always be representative of the conditions under which new particle formation takes place. Inability to distinguish between ground-level and elevated new particle formation events is contributing to inconsistencies in the factors that are proposed toinfluence new particle formation.

We hypothesized that the vertical turbulent fluxes of 3 - 10 nm-sized particles can be used to distinguish between ground-level and elevated new particle formation events. To test this hypothesis, the team from North Carolina State University deployed their instrumentation to the Department of Energy Atmospheric Radiation Measurement user facility at the Southern Great Plain site in Oklahoma (See Figure 1). This research site offered the unprecedented opportunity of frequent new particle formation events paired with exceptional logistical and staff support. Our experiments found that strong increases in 3 - 10 nm-sized particle concentrations happened at the same time as new particle formation events were detected by aerosol sizing instrumentation. These increases generally coincided with a measured downward turbulent flux of particles, suggesting that the new particle formation events originated aloft.

Although a more in-depth understanding of particle advection by the mean flow as well as transport by atmospheric turbulence and diffusion is needed, our study concluded that turbulent flux measurements of 3 -10 nm size particles can provide a good indication for the vertical location of new particle formation events. We anticipate that the methodology developed in this study will help scientists to better differentiate ground-level and elevated new particle formation events and improve the quantification of the factors influencing nucleation. Ultimately this should lead to a more accurate representation of new particle formation in regional and global climate models.
